p: Our estimate of water cycle sensitivity to warming based on our CMIP5 ensemble (~4.3%/°C) is very close to the estimate of Durack et al. 4 based on the CMIP3 ensemble of E-P PA (~4.5%/°C). It is interesting to note that in climate models total P is increasing at a significantly lower rates (~3.4%/°C, Allen and Ingram 3; ~2%/°C, Held and Soden 2; 3.1%/°C, Durack et al. 4 - than the global E-P pattern (~4.5%/°C, Durack et al. 4). Although precipitation extremes are shown to follow CC scaling, the total global average precipitation, commonly referred to as the strength of the water cycle in climate sciences, is constrained by the atmospheric radiative energy balance (e.g. Allen and Ingram 3, Held and Soden 2). A change in the water cycle well below the CC rate was exhibited by the majority of coupled climate models (Allen and Ingram 3; Held and Soden 2; Durack et al. 4).
